Sunday Jan 7 1866
This morning we moved about 3 miles westward along the foot of the Mts & then Northerly about 5 miles to the foot of a timbered ravine and camped at a point where timber could be obtained
Monday Jan 8 1866
I left the camp in charge of Sergt Matthews and after giving all necessary instructions I returned to Camp [?Neight?]
Tuesday Jan 9 1866
Night cold.  Morning foggy.  We have no thermometer but would guess that the mercury for some time would range at 20 or 25 below 0.  The snow has settled to about 4 inches at camp while down below about the Lakes it appears to be bare in places
Wed. Jan 10, 1866
Snowed during the night, day calm
Thursday Jan 11 1866
Sergt Matthews who has charge of the working party at the Mountains signalized camp last night by a system of fires previously agreed upon and two wagons were sent out to bring in their baggage and lumber
Friday Jan 12 1866
Snowed about 2 inches deep last night.  Day cold & still

2
the reports of the various departments.  The paper work as it is often called of an Expedition of this nature is quite sufficient to give constant employment to two or three active penmen, but in the absence of men who were able to transact business the most of it if not all fell upon me.   Hence I never knew what if was to have a leisure moment in camp.  For the last 6 weeks the weather has been severely cold and our sod houses not the warmest, while our sage brush fires fell far short of rendering us comfortable.
Many a long dreary day I was compelled to write all day with my great coat and gloves on and that too while sitting along side of as comfortable a fire as it was practicable for us to make
My ink had to be set in the ashes to prevent it from freezing and during a great part of the time for a month and a half the ink would freeze solid on the pen point before it would become exhausted.  At all of such times the  pen point would be thrust into the blaze for two or three seconds and at once be ready for use again.  and thus was the great part of the office work of the Silvers River Expedition performed in Carney Lake Valley Oregon during the long and dreary winter of 1865 & 6

Saturday Jan 13 1866
About ½ inch of fine snow fell during the night [?] still & extremely cold
Sunday Jan 14 1866
A thick fog this morning and everything white with frost which fell like snow during the day
Monday Jan 15 1866
Col.  Wind South. blowed hard all day.  Sergt Matthews with teams [?men?] and timber came in from the Mountains.
Tuesday Jan 16 1866
The morning was cloudy and very cold.  Our poor pack train, which has frequently been reported "unserviceable" by the Quarter Master was started out for Camp Curry today Corpl McPherson in charge of the escort
Wednesday Jan 17 1866
Cold morning.  west wind.  Snow squally
Thursday Jan 18 1866 & 19 1866
Colder than usual.  still - But very few people except those who have been in the Military service have any idea of the vast amount of labor necessary to be performed in keeping the proper records,  and in making out the

gradually softened and in the PM became sloppy again
Wed Jan 24 1866
Rained during the night.  day calm & wet
Thursday Jan 25 1866
Snow crusty.  the Pack train was again sent to Camp Curry
Friday Jan 26 1866
Froze up solid, but thawed during the day, snow settling fast, the south side hills and southern slopes are bare also the mountains and hills around the Lakes
Saturday Jan 27 1866
At two oclock this morning the officer of the day Lieut Bowen woke me up and reported the following that the Indians were about camp that they had approached the Packers tent which was on the River about 50 yds above the Guard house that they had torn the tent down and cut it in pieces and carried the most of it away.  that the Sentinel on post had heard the noise & had reported it to the Corpl of the Guard who had walked out in that direction and in the bright moon shine had seen the Indians run away.  somehow without firing at them. he then called out the guard and proceeded to awake

Saturday Jan 20 1866
Five inches of snow fell during the night which continued during the day and at night was 18 inches deep
Sunday Jan 21 1866
A warm night, day wet and misty.  snow packed and settled fast during the day
Monday Jan 22 1866
Snow wet & sloppy this morning thawed all day.  much water under the snow.  the train and escort came in from Camp Curry and brought the following intelligence.  That the detachment mentioned on the 28th Dec that had left Camp Curry for Camp Watson had returned being unable to get through the snow and that Maj. Perry the Comdg Officer at that Camp had started out with 30 men and the necessary transportation with a view of opening a trail through the snow to communicate with Camp Watson and the outside world.  he was absent 5 days & finding the snow too deep for his Pack animals he was obliged to return having lost his first Sergt by freezing to death in the snow
Tuesday Jan 23 18
a hard crust in the snow but

safety our our [sic] animals. which only had an escort of 7 men. I sent out Lieut Applegate with 12 men more to meet the train on the road
Day pleasant but cold. one man came in bring an express from Camp Curry and reported the following that Sergt Reed of Co "G" [?rgm?] Cavalry stationed at Camp Watson had crossed over the Mountains on Snow shoes and brought the meloncholly intelligence that our regular expressman had perished in the snow having been found by a small hunting party of the Camp Watson soldiers a short distance from that camp. and before life was extinct. he told them where he had left his mule arms  & accoutrements and mail matter.  It appears he was travelling over the heavy timbered summit a few miles South of Camp Watson and had become frozen. and abandoned his mule & hung his express matter  on a limb and in his dispair had made in unsuccessful attempt to blow his brains out and had snapped several caps in his revolver and failing in that he had left everything and wandered off in the direction of Camp Watson where he was found by the soldiers near

the officer of the day and he had reported to me as before stated and as the Indians now had at least 15 minutes the start, a night chase appeared useless.
At daylight the Indians tracks were found, five in number.  they  had come up from the direction of Malheur Lake and had returned in the same direction.  Our train was gone and no pursuit could be made.  we followed their trail however about 6 miles & found they were going in the direction of the bare ground around the East front of Malheur Lake.  Blood hounds had been previously recommended by me and if we had them they might been used with great satisfaction today. 
Sunday Jan 28 1866
Thawed during the day. large ponds of ice and water is to be seen everywhere on the plain and along the River
Monday Jan 29 1866
Snow is pretty much off the valley around camp except where it drifted during the heavy wind.  Having some anxiety in regard to the

5
small escorts continue to be sent out with trains from one Camp to another through this region of Country during the coming summer it is quite probable that a disaster may occur sooner or later and a train captured & men massacred for the reason that they have not a proper escort.
Jan 31 & Feb 1  1866
Freezing nights, and damp thawy days 
Friday Feb 2d 1866
Cold and frozen and dark cloudy this morning: With 20 Infy & 10 dismounted Cavalry I set out for the south side of Harney Lake on a scout after Indians .travelled 12 miles in a course S.S.W. and fell upon the slough Connecting Malheur & Harney Lake which at this place is about a mile wide. and we had Contemplated crossing over to the South side on the Ice.  but as it had thawed considerable of late. and the ice being soft and open in places rendered it unsafe to cross our animals. whereupon we camped for the night.
Saturday Feb 3d 1866
We proceeded down the channel to its entrance in to Harney Lake where we soon arrived. the Channel

that camp.  I can hardly account for his death. always lived in a cold and snowy country and why he did not stop and build fires to keep himself warm is more than I can imagine.  His name was Bird and was raised on the Red River of the North.
Sergt Reed reports the snow on the Camp Watson Mts. about 12 feet deep
Tuesday Jan 30 1866
Froze hard last night  the pack train came in at 4 P.M. and the Camp Curry train came with it with an escort of 4 men to escort it back.  A pack train with only 4 men for an escort is sufficiently protected provided there is no danger. but a small force of Indians could [?] a train terribly with no better protection. and a dozen Indians choosing their own ground for an attack. which they generally do would be very likely to Capture the animals and kill the men.
A train of a dozen animals if any escort is required should have at least 15 men and those resolute.  And if such

existed provided the bottom did not prove too soft.  I therefore sent McCoy one of the Packers to bring up a riding animal from where we had encamped  a few yards back, and sent him in to examine the water as I directed and had the satisfaction of finding an excellent ford with a smooth and hard sandy bottom.

     All around this Lake and Malheur Lake the snow has been off for some time . while at Camp Wright hard crusty snow is yet found in drifts and patches and at the upper or north end of the Valley 15 miles further all on apparently the same level the snow is nearly a foot deep yet
    Very much has been said about these Lakes . another prevailing opinion has always been that if any current at all between them that the flow was from Harney to Malheur Lake. but at this time quite a perceptible current is flowing into Harney Lake
   The water in the Lake and Slough during the summer season is entirely unfit for use while at present the slough affords very good water while the Lake water is salt and bitter and strongly tinctured

ice at this place was entirely gone from the channel. and the lake for nearly a quarter of a mile.  The Lake was frozen solid the ice being about a foot thick but smooth & glassy so that we dared not venture upon it with our barefooted pack mules
This channel or neck where it enters Harney Lake is not over 40 feet wide and has always been represented by [?] Military and others as being unfordable and Capt Currys (now Col Curry) expedition in 1864 had met with great inconvenience and delay by not being able to cross at this place and in consequence thereof was obliged to travel around the West end of the Lake. and this Silver River Expedition has been foiled in some of its scouts and also inconvenienced by believing this Channel unfordable as so often represented.
This was my first visit to this spot and its general appearance indicated that it might be forded by keeping out into the Lake to where the bar actually

been made very recently in the mud but the camp had been abandoned a day or two. On the stream about 2 miles above this little Lake we encamped for the night and the men were divided up into small parties and sent out into different different [sic] directions but no Indians were discovered and no further Camps or sign was to be found.

 By a regular system of guard it fell with Cav soldiers to guard duty to night and Corpl Walsh was the officer in charge!  In consequence of the Indians in the immediate vicinity I ordered 3 posts to be kept up tonight instead of two as formerly & this order created some murmuring among those who were going on guard for the night and even Lieut Bowen of the Cav could not exactly understand that any necessity existed for any extra guard duty or that the number of Posts should be increased.


Monday Feb 5 1866
Last night proved to be an unfortunate night - for as the wind blew heavily from the South, the pack animals were placed upon a small patch of grass near Camp with a

with Alkali
Sunday Feb 4 1866
We forded the channel this morning with our Pack animals . while the men passed around on the ice of the Lake.  Following the Lake shore southerly about 3 miles we noticed fog and vapor rising from near the foot of the sage hills about a half mile to our left which proved to be a cluster of hot springs of 20 or more in number forming a brisk stream of 6 or 8 feet wide running off  [?] Lake
Passing along to the Slough - now we came upon a small Lake situated in a level sage valley with no outlet, but a rapid and brisk stream flowing into it from the South.  At this place we saw an Indian running on the distant hills who soon disappeared while a few newly [?] and ranches made of sage bush was also discovered but all had been abandoned

  The Indian [?walks?] around appeared to have

Sentinel on each side as usual.  All was quiet until 10 oclock when Corpl Walsh instead of going out with the relief sent Private John G. Mackey out of camp by himself to relieve the Sentinel about 20 steps away and when about half the distance, he was struck by an Arrow upon the right elbow.  turning at once in the direction the arrow had come he saw the Indian and fired at him and at almost the same instant he was struck with another arrow over the left hip which entered the body about 6 inches inflicting a Mortal wound.  He gave the alarm of Indians . and the men were instantly tuned out but the Indians had gone:  The wounded man was brought in. suffering much and I drew the Arrow out of his body but it was impossible to do so without drawing off the barbed obsidian point which tore loose when about half way out:  The wound in the arm being of minor importance, but little attention was paid to it.  Mackey was more worried for fear the Arrow was a poison one. than otherwise

but after being assured that the Snakes did not use poisonous arrows he appeared more relieved. however it mattered but little to the poor unfortunate sufferer for from the general Character of the wound it is quite certain he can not survive long  At 2 oclock in the morning the Camp was again alarmed by a brisk fire from the Sentinels.  I was out at once and Camp was soon in arms but soon became quiet.  Then Sentinels reported that Indians had approached and fired into Camp with a rifle. that they had seen the flash about 50 yards off and the Corpl had directed them to fire towards the flash had been seen.

  At 3 oclock the officer of the Guard woke me up and announced that poor Mackey was dieing. which proved to be the case for he was dead before I reached his bed: I had a faint hope the man might live and based that hope upon the fact that I had once been shot with an arrow in just about the same place which ranged in the same direction and penetrated just about the same depth. yet I had lived by dragging out about 8 years of a miserable existence
  In examining the place this morning where Mackey was

[Duplicate of preceding page]
Sentinel on each side as usual.  All was quiet until 10 oclock when Corpl Walsh instead of going out with the relief sent Private John G. Mackey out of camp by himself to relieve the Sentinel about 20 steps away and when about half the distance, he was struck by an Arrow upon the right elbow.  turning at once in the direction the arrow had come he saw the Indian and fired at him and at almost the same instant he was struck with another arrow over the left hip which entered the body about 6 inches inflicting a Mortal wound.  He gave the alarm of Indians . and the men were instantly tuned out but the Indians had gone:  The wounded man was brought in. suffering much and I drew the Arrow out of his body but it was impossible to do so without drawing off the barbed obsidian point which tore loose when about half way out:  The wound in the arm being of minor importance, but little attention was paid to it.  Mackey was more worried for fear the Arrow was a poison one. than otherwise

shot. It was found by the tracks in the sand that only two Inds had approached Camp. and they had run off when Mackey fired losing 3 very nicely made obsidian pointed arrows. following their tracks about 150 yds we found where two others had stood with guns the marks of which were seen as the [sic] had rested them in the sand.

 Believing it to be our sacred duty to return to Camp Wright to bury our dear Comrad . we set out this morning in our return. packing the Corpse up  on a Mule.
  We arrived at the Ford at the mouth of the Malheur slough and crossed over safely. and travelled a mile or two & Camped.

Tuesday Feb 6 1866
Arrived at Camp Wright in the P.M. to learn that an Indian had been prowling around Camp during the [evn'ng?] previous and had been twice fired at by the Sentinel but unfortunately he had escaped . His track was found where he had come up from Malheur Lake & he had returned in the same direction

Wednesday Feb 7 1866
The Soldier Mackey was buried today at 3 oclock P.M. with Military honors: His grave was made about 50 yds East from the front of the mountain back of our Camp it being a level spot of dry sandy ground and as appropriate a place as we cold select
Thursday Feb 8 1866
Thawed during the day, ground muddy
Friday Feb 9 1866
Lieut Grant A. A. Q. M. with 10 men set out for Camp Curry to procure further supplies if possible.  Corpl McPherson and Privates James B. Buell and Anderson C. Brown whose terms of service have expired also leaves to day for Dept Hd Qrs to be mustered out of service
Saturday Feb 10 1866
Pleasant. but did not thaw enough to soften the mud on top
Sunday Feb 11 1865 [sic]
Froze hard last night, day cloudy
Monday Feb 12 1865 [corrected to 1866]
Ground frozen solid, bright day. calm. I sent Lt Applegate & 13 men down River in the direction of Malheur Lake . No discoveries were made

[Duplicate of preceding page]
shot. It was found by the tracks in the sand that only two Inds had approached Camp. and they had run off when Mackey fired losing 3 very nicely made obsidian pointed arrows. following their tracks about 150 yds we found where two others had stood with guns the marks of which were seen as the [sic] had rested them in the sand.

 Believing it to be our sacred duty to return to Camp Wright to bury our dear Comrad . we set out this morning in our return. packing the Corpse up  on a Mule.
  We arrived at the Ford at the mouth of the Malheur slough and crossed over safely. and travelled a mile or two & Camped.

Tuesday Feb 6 1866
Arrived at Camp Wright in the P.M. to learn that an Indian had been prowling around Camp during the [evn'ng?] previous and had been twice fired at by the Sentinel but unfortunately he had escaped . His track was found where he had come up from Malheur Lake & he had returned in the same direction

Tuesday Feb 13 1866
A cold morning. but pleasant day
Wed. Feb 14 1866
Last night was colder than usual . ice froze about an inch thick on the ponds   Lieut Grant returned in the afternoon and reported to me in person , that he had been to Camp Curry and as directed . he had made application for provisions for our men and grain for our Pack animals but had failed altogether . The A.A. Q.M. at that camp having sufficient to subsist that camp until the first of May . therefore nothing could be spared from that Camp:  My Command was only rationed to March 20 - and no meat of any kind at that . we were therefore about to become short of supplies altogether at a time where it would be impossible, except in case of actual starvation for supplies to be brought in or for us to go out where anything could be obtained

    It was expected that we were to be supplied from Camp Curry until May 1 1866. Col Curry so intended it. and Capt

Scott and myself both so understood it. but after we were shut in by the winter snows. the orders were interpreted differently which prevented us from doing the Indian scouting we had expected during the winter. which had cut off our supply of grain for our Pack animals. and also our Commissary stores for the support of the Command. all of which might have been remedied before winter set in

  It would [sic] been really absurd for any officer to order an extredition into this Country in winter and only supplies until the month of March, for that is a time when it is just as impracticable and even more so to transport supplies into this region as any time during the winter
  It therefore became necessary to reduce our rations at once although we have no meat for some time

Feb 15-16-17 & 18
Cold nights but bright pleasant days -

Monday Feb   19 1866
No change in the weather  I was out about 10 miles East of camp with a dozen men but saw no indication that any Indians had been near Camp in that direction
Tuesday & Wednesday
No change in weather
Thursday Feb 22
This being a [?] holliday all business was suspended except Guard duty . A national salute was fired from our Mountain Howitzer at noon.
Friday Feb 23 1866
Cold morning . clear and bright
Sent Lieut Applegate out a few miles to scout . he returned with a few Rabbits
Feb 24 & 25
Cold nights & pleasant days
Monday Feb 26 1866
The surface of the ground becomes muddy every day and freezes solid every night.  An expressman came in from Camp Curry and reported the following . that he had arrived at Camp Curry from Camp Watson two weeks ago . and had started from there

with our mail matter for this camp that when about 15 miles from Camp Curry he was fired upon by Indians who had chased him on foot for some distance. he therefore turned back to Camp Curry . The Indians failing in their attempt to Capture the expressman succeeded in running off five soldiers from their Camp on Silver Creek where they had been encamped for some time in Guarding a hay stack . there were not over a half dozen Indians but the men became frightened and ran away leaving one Rifle Musket and two Cartridge boxes of Ammunition . their blankets & a part of their clothes which they did not happen just at the moment to have on

   For such a cowardly act soldiers should not be excused

Thursday Feb 27 1866
Day warm. Windy. thawy & muddy
Wednesday Feb 28 1866
Slightly frozen this morning.  Wind S.W.  General Muster and Inspection day   Saw the first wild geese today . Which are expected to come in large numbers as soon as the ice is out of the Lakes and swamps, been out of meat we are looking anxiously forward to the time when ducks & geese may be obtained

[Duplicate of preceding page]
Tuesday & Wednesday
No change in weather
Thursday Feb 22
This being a [?] holliday all business was suspended except Guard duty . A national salute was fired from our Mountain Howitzer at noon.
Friday Feb 23 1866
Cold morning . clear and bright
Sent Lieut Applegate out a few miles to scout . he returned with a few Rabbits
Feb 24 & 25
Cold nights & pleasant days
Monday Feb 26 1866
The surface of the ground becomes muddy every day and freezes solid every night.  An expressman came in from Camp Curry and reported the following . that he had arrived at Camp Curry from Camp Watson two weeks ago . and had started from there

Friday March 2d 1866
With a half dozen good hunters I went down to the swampy ground 8 or ten miles below camp . can see no sign of Indians about  - day cold & chilly.  killed a few rabbits
Saturday March 3 1866
A frosty morning and cold wind all day from N.E. scouted up River about 6 miles found much water on the flats above also a great deal of Ice which is fast breaking up.  Ducks and Geese begin to appear in flocks and are hovering around the sloughs which are now filled with ice & water to overflowing
Sunday March  4 1866
A beautiful warm spring day
Monday March 5 1866
Many flocks of Geese passed over last night. day warm. SW. wind  the River is beginning to rise gradually and the prospects are that much water will appear in the valley in a few days
Tuesday March 6 1866
A warm night. light South wind snow banks in the Valley are disappearing fast, in fact are pretty much gone   scouted up the River 5 or 6 miles found the River

Thursday March 1 1866
Lieut Grant reported to me in writing last night that our supplies at our present reduced rations would not hold out over 20 days longer and as it is impossible for any to arrive by that time it therefore has become necessary for some action to be had at once.  I therefore made a detail of 42 men under Lieuts Grant and Applegate to proceed at once with all the transportation of the Command and 12 days rations reduced as they are to Camp Watson with Instructions to Lieut Grant to procure further transportation and supplies & return at once:  the men set out glad to be moving in a direction where full rations Could be obtained yet dreading the prospect before them. for at this season of the year it is not an easy matter for a company of men with animals to cross over the snowy Mts. on the route

  The remainder of the Command will now be able to measure out their rations a few days longer  Yet it cannot be possible that we will receive aid from the outside world by the time our supplies are consumed.

13
the surrounding plain.  A raise of about 2 feet more would overflow miles and miles of the sage plain in fact 20 inches more will innundate our camp.  The high water mark appears to be about reached
March 13. 14 & 15
Cold freezing nights and bright pleasant days
Friday March 16 1866
A flat Boat had been constructed from the lumber brought from the Mts and this morning with a dozen men I set out down River with a view of prospecting the Lakes for Indians and game waterfowl being now very abundant:  at 3 miles from Camp where we had cut hay last fall we found the country over flowed and appeared like an extensive swamp or marsh

 At about  3 miles farther the Stream appeared to divide and run off in two channels & following the right hand channel which appeared the most prominent for two or three miles when the stream appeared to break off in small channels when at last we was stopped by coming to the end of the River or in other words to where the whole thing terminated

free from ice and raising in many places large sloughs connect with the River & extend back for a mile or two into the valley or plain  as as [sic] the River raises these sloughs become gradually filled forming favorite haunts for water fowl which every day appear more and more plenty but are very wild
7 & 8  no change
Friday March 9, 1866
a dark and dismal day, rain & snow intermixed fell all day.  snow melting as fast as it fell.  Wind S.W.
Saturday the 10
A cold night followed by a pleasant day
Sunday the 11
Ground froze solid, but became muddy before noon.  River raised about a foot last night
Monday March 12
Morning cold.  fine snow falling which continued until about 10 oclock when the storm abated & snow soon melted off - river raised about 12 inches last night is now almost on a level with the

Wednesday March 21 1866
Still.   cloudy & warm
Thursday March 22 1866
Snow an inch deep but was soon gone.  River raising an inch or so each day
Friday March 23d & Saturday 24 & 25
Warm & showery
Monday 26th
We expected Lieut Grant back on the 20th and have been anxiously looking for him ever since.  he has now been gone 26 days and no intelligence whatever has been recd.  our supplies nearly consumed.  Rations again reduced.  We have now half rations of flour, no meat, half rations of beans, no sugar.  Bread & beans straight and not enough of that.
Tuesday March 27 1866
Again set out down River with the Boat in search of game.  we saw waterfowl in astonishing numbers but very wild.  a few birds were killed by firing in to large flocks a quarter and one half mile away
March 28 & 29  fair & pleasant

in an extensive swamp extending to Malheur Lake a few miles further down   Returning to the more easterly channel we drifted down that about 1 1/2 miles when we found it to terminate in the same manner.   This put an end to our boat navigation.  We therefore returned to Camp where we arrived at about sundown
We saw large flocks of Snow Geese, Ducks and Sandhill cranes which have congregated in the swamp land in vast numbers but they appear very wild so much so that could not get nearer than a quarter of a mile of them and the nearer we approached the Lake the more numerous they appeared and their cries & screams in that direction was one continuous roar
March 17 & 18
Days clear & pleasant & nights cold
Monday March 19 1866
A cold morning ground white with snow  snow squally all day
Tuesday March 20 1866
West wind blasting.  Snow squalls at short intervals

15
one of the peculiar workings of the subsistence department that we could not be furnished without express orders from Head Quarters but we presume it is all right & no one to blame.

  We have been without meat sugar, tea & coffee for many weeks  No supplies but flour and Beans while we yet afford our regular 7 oz. of flour and a half ration of beans for day to a man it is found that all hands have become weak and poor and many have slight symptoms of the Scurvy:  A kind of weed resembling a turnip top grows in the Sage bush & makes a very good salad and regular details of men are made every day to pick and gather this vegetable and it is regularly served up

And meat is so much needed that Cayotes and crows are killed and eaten, and muskrats appearing quite plenty along the River are hunted and killed and considered a great delicacy

 Officers and men fared equally alike and it was amusing to see Lieut Bowen who had been [?11?] years in the service & fared sumptuously in comfortable quarters [crossed out: every]

Friday March 30 1866
At 11 oclock last night an Express came in from Camp Watson and I learned that Lieut Grant reached Camp Watson in 17 days that the route was bad and the snow deep in the mountains, that no transportation could be obtained, that the Condition of our Animals were such that he could not return short of three or 4 weeks.  Official letters from Head Quarters directs the Comdg officer at Camp Curry to furnish us as far as practicable until supplies can be sent [?here?]:  The Comdg officer at that Camp, Maj Perry of the Reg. 14 U.S. Infy. informs me that "pursuant to orders" he will furnish us supplies, which had previously been refused:

   How much benefit this would been to the service and how much suffering and exposure it would have saved this expedition if supplies could have been furnished previous to our men being ordered to Camp Watson and as the same amount of supplies were on hand at that time as now it appears to me to be

16
Tuesday April 3 1866
Day warm & thawy, a little rain & snow all gone before night
April 4 - 5 - &6
Pleasant warm
Sunday April 7 1866
The expressman came in last night from Camp Curry and reports the following. that Indians had been prowling around that Camp. and on the night of the 5 had attempted to steal their pack animals out of their corrall:  It appears they had got inside of the Corall which was made of poles about 6 inches in diameter. and had actually succeeded in Cutting one or two of these small logs in two with their knives . and that while the Sentinels were walking around the Corrall one in each direction at the same time, and had taken out two horses and run away with them
Sunday & Monday pleasant
The pack train from Camp Curry Came in bringing us a supply of flour . but nothing further.  I at once issued an order increasing the flour ration

March forth daily to secure his regular crow or Muskrat to season his reduced ration of Bean soup:  A few ducks and geese were killed but no mess ever obtained sufficient for a square meal in their reduced condition
Saturday March 31
Cloudy.  light west wind
Sunday April 1 1866
According to Army Regulations winter ends with the last of March and summer begins with the first of April but what a mistake this time  This morning the snow is 2 inches deep and is snowing furiously.  wind cold from N.W.  the snow Continued falling until afternoon.  at which time it subsided being about 4 inches deep

  Today I sent Lieut Bowen & 18 Cavalry to Camp Curry & also made a requisition upon that Camp for further supplies and for their train to pack the same to us

Monday April 2 1866
A winter morning . wind north  snow dry & crusty

among which was 3 Springfield muskets and their accoutrements and a considerable quantity of Cartridges and also a small amount of Clothing.  Camp and Garrison Equippage.  Considering the rapid spread of the flames the men done admirably to save As much property as they did and while some of them saved their own personal effects many of them had all their clothes burned except what they happened to have on their person at this particular time
Tuesday April 24 1866
Pleasant and warm.  Wind west
Wednesday April 26 1866
Rained during the day.  Lieut Grant & an Express came in with the Pack train from Camp Watson and Camp Curry today.    He reported that he could obtain no supplies and brought no news as to future operations or as to any supplies being on the way:  Rations reduced still further to about 1/2 ration of flour an [sic] a full ration of beans
April 27 - 28 & 29
Bright and pleasant days.  Grass fine.  Water still at its height in the valley

How much the men wished for the inferior quality of pork commonly called "Sowbelly" among soldiers and which they had so terribly denounced about a year ago:  But we were now in fair circumstances with a pound of flour for day and half ration of Beans seasoned with whatever we might be lucky enough to kill.  Swan, goose, duck muskrat, cayote - or crow
Wednesday 11
Train returned to Fort Curry weather remained pleasant for several days.  passed  our time in hunting, considerable game was killed and nothing to change the regular routine of Camp life until
Monday April 23 1866
Today Camp Wright suffered severely by fire at about 2 oclock P.M. a smoke was discovered on the N.W. corner which indicated fire and in less than 5 minutes the entire inside of the Company Quarters on that side of the Parade Ground was in a perfect flame  Much property was burned

[Picture postcard with printed identification: Stanley Dell                   Sarony, Major & Knapp. Lith.s  449 Broadway NY
picture shows a covered wagon accompanied by a rider and a pack animal crossing a flat area between rolling hills]

Monday April 30 1866
Had general muster and inspection at 8 oclock.

 Much suffering is experienced by our rations being from time to time reduced - We still have a half ration of flour and about 2/3 ration of beans for day.  The men are poor and emaciated and many of them have symptoms of the Scurvy
  A vegetable diet is about the only preventive and our details are sent out daily to gather the wild turnip top for salad which still holds out and covered with vinegar is a preventive I think has prevented our men from being worse than they otherwise would been.  Geese ducks, Swan and Cranes are in the valley by hundreds of thousands but are so wild that it is difficult to kill them.  Occasionally a few are killed by firing into large flocks 1/4 mile or more away - a few muskrats are killed by the men every day and are doing much in sustaining us in our miserable situation
    Officers and men fare alike and each squad are commanded to pick their own salad and kill their own muskrats.  While an equal

distribution of game is sometimes made when a party meets with no success and others have unusual good luck - A Goose - duck or muskrat, or even a crow or the leg of a wolf or cayote to a mess of a half dozen makes good seasoning, for their soup.  Beans straight without meat is generally considered a not very delicate dish but under present circumstances the addition of a wolfs hind leg is as choice a dish as any of us can wish for.

 The time having arrived for me to act myself finding that my quarter master and Commissary force has failed altogether in supplying our Camp - I set out this morning for Camp Curry and Camp Watson if necessary with the pack train and one wagon to obtain supplies if possible. our flour being nearly consumed - We proceeded up the valley and made Camp on a little spring valley about 16 miles from Camp Wright
 Two or three ducks and three or four mud hens were killed & a hat full or two of Eggs principally mud hens and ducks eggs were found
 I had in addition to our pack train and 6 mule team a small detachment of Cavalry and also of Infantry

[Duplicate of two pages back]
Monday April 30 1866
Had general muster and inspection at 8 oclock.

 Much suffering is experienced by our rations being from time to time reduced - We still have a half ration of flour and about 2/3 ration of beans for day.  The men are poor and emaciated and many of them have symptoms of the Scurvy
  A vegetable diet is about the only preventive and our details are sent out daily to gather the wild turnip top for salad which still holds out and covered with vinegar is a preventive I think has prevented our men from being worse than they otherwise would been.  Geese ducks, Swan and Cranes are in the valley by hundreds of thousands but are so wild that it is difficult to kill them.  Occasionally a few are killed by firing into large flocks 1/4 mile or more away - a few muskrats are killed by the men every day and are doing much in sustaining us in our miserable situation
    Officers and men fare alike and each squad are commanded to pick their own salad and kill their own muskrats.  While an equal

Tuesday May 1 1866
An early start soon brought us to the long range of Sage Hills with now and then a Juniper as we ascend in the direction of Silver Creek.  When about a half mile to one side a small band of Antelope were seen - I hastily rode out to where they had entered a narrow ravine tied my mule to a chunk of Lava crept up, Carefully and succeeded in killing one of the Animals.  This was joyful intelligence and at night the men had a rousing meal. while I proceeded on to Camp Curry.
Wednesday May 2 1866
Day fair.  the train came in together with the wagon about noon
Thursday May 3 1866
Lieut Grant our Q.M. & C.S. have been absent 57 days and had been unsuccessful in his Efforts to obtain supplies - I made an affecting appeal to the Major (Perry) Comdg at this place, stating my intention to set out at once for Camp Watson and to Head Quarters at Fort Vancouver if necessary in case I

failed to obtain the necessary supplies for the present from him

   I had the satisfaction to find that I could obtain supplies of all kinds except meat, that a bull only remained of their Beef Cattle & as the Troops at Camp Curry had had their regular beef up to a day or two ago they had not yet attacked the Bull.  I took advantage of that circumstance to urge our claims and the Bull also was turned over to me - and we soon set out with our train and wagon pretty well loaded, driving our bull before us and camped on Silver Creek 12 miles below.  the day was unpleasant Cold and Snow squally, but the men were cheerful and were speculating as to the surprise we would give our men at Camp Wright when they should see us coming with supplies and a live Bull
  Late in the afternoon an Expressman was seen coming from towards Camp Curry bringing us intelligence from head Quarters to abandon Camp Wright and move at once to Camp Curry while the Command at the latter camp was to remove to Fort Boise in Idaho

to take all the volunteer forces to Camp Watson as soon as practicable
Wednesday May 9
Issued orders opening Command of the Post - Train and wagons came in from Camp Wright
Thursday May 10 1866
The command at present is made up of fragments of different Companies - I detailed Lieut Barlow 1st [?] Inf to take charge of attachments of "H & K" Cos and proceed to Camp Watson & Sergt Kelsay of [?] Co. with a detacht [sic] to return to Camp Wright - & move up the remainder of the men and stores
May 11, 12. 13 & 14
Fair weather
Tuesday May 15 1866
The majors and all the men arrived today from Camp Wright
Wednesday May 16 1866
With Lieut Bowen, Dr. Davis & 9 mounted men I set out on a small or short scout in a Southwesterly Course into a range of low mountains where snow was lying in patches & which immediate section has not even been explored and

Friday May 4 1866
Last night a sundown I gave orders for the train.  major & men to return today to Camp with the supplies except flour and then proceed to Camp Wright.  while with one man I set out and arrived at that Camp about 2 oclock this morning to make preparations for breaking up Camp and moving to Camp Curry
Saturday May 5
Snow Squally & unpleasant
Sunday May 6 1866
Pack train Came in today & we prepared to move tomorrow
Monday May 7
Set out with train & 2 remaining wagons & 26 men and Camped at the usual Camp ground
Tuesday May 8 1866
I went on in advance and reached Camp Curry at 2 PM and met Col Sinclair and Maj Perry with 112 men en route for Fort Boise:  The Col having just arrived from Camp Watson with a part of his Command

 At Camp Curry I recd orders

[picture postcard with the following commercial printing along the bottom edge:  a. Lewis and Clarks Pass b.  Heart Mountain   Sarony, Major & Knapp Liths. 449 Broadway NY ]

traveled about 23 miles and camped upon some small spring branches just below the visible snow.  We passed several small lakes or ponds of alkali water in the sage plains which generally abound with waterfowl at this season.  A swan was killed and some ducks and several Cayotes fired at From the snowy heights just above us the range of heavy timbered Mts along the Deschutes River was plainly visible.  Diamond Peak N.80 [degrees] [?] at the head of the Middle fork of the Willamette and Mt. McLaughlin S. 75 [degrees] [?] at the head of Rogue River were each distinctly visible about 100 miles away while at least 75 of the 100 was a barren desert, treeless and destitute of water. but covered with Sage brush sand and broken rock
Thursday May 17 1866
Set out on our return and arrived at Camp in the   P.M.  We found a trail of Indians perhaps 30 or 40 strong who who [sic] had passed along about 2 weeks before us in the direction of Steens Mountain.  They appeared to have had cattle

21
and horses while many of them were on foot - They had probably been down in John Days River somewhere & made a raid upon some of the Ranches
Friday May 18 1866
Two Inches snow today, but melted off before night
May 19-20-21 & 22
Fair, pleasant &c
Wednesday May 23d 
We packed up today preparatory to a start tomorrow
Thursday May 24 1866
The men were in gay spirits last night at their prospects of an early return to full rations and a muster out of service
They marched over the Parade ground in splendid order to the sound of Martial Music, accompanied by brilliant torch light processions and illuminations
For want of transportation it had become necessary to destroy much property (old & worn) and consequently large bonfires blazed at short Intervals- The men were given the entire freedom of the Camp & their enjoyment was at its full -
We set out this morning in a

[duplicate of an earlier page]  
traveled about 23 miles and camped upon some small spring branches just below the visible snow.  We passed several small lakes or ponds of alkali water in the sage plains which generally abound with waterfowl at this season.  A swan was killed and some ducks and several Cayotes fired at From the snowy heights just above us the range of heavy timbered Mts along the Deschutes River was plainly visible.  Diamond Peak N.80 [degrees] [?] at the head of the Middle fork of the Willamette and Mt. McLaughlin S. 75 [degrees] [?] at the head of Rogue River were each distinctly visible about 100 miles away while at least 75 of the 100 was a barren desert, treeless and destitute of water. but covered with Sage brush sand and broken rock
Thursday May 17 1866
Set out on our return and arrived at Camp in the   P.M.  We found a trail of Indians perhaps 30 or 40 strong who who [sic] had passed along about 2 weeks before us in the direction of Steens Mountain.  They appeared to have had cattle

left, and after making about 6 miles we camped at a place named by the Parkers Burnt Camp - this place has a small stream of water running northerly to Beaver Creek.
Monday May 28 1866
Lieut Bowen and three citizens who was going from California to the John Day mines and who had overtaken us yesterday all set out together in [?advance?] for Camp Watson 45 miles distant  We had good mules and after Giving all necessary instructions we set out at quite a rapid rate over the low hills for about 12 miles for Beaver Creek which was quite high but easy fordable.

 Leaving Dahlgren Creek to our left travelling over rough and Rocky ground a few miles and entered the timbered Country on the Southern Slope of the Camp Watson Mountains - The surface of the ground as we approach the Mountains is found to be extremely muddy and slow progress is made, however we pushed on and at about sundown we was at the summit on top of solid snow several feet deep and our animals could easily walk on top of it

We soon descend out of the snow

drizzling rain N. Westerly upon the crooked River Road and at about 3 miles entered a region of fine timbered hills which continued about 15 miles when we descend a long and steep slope to Buik Creek a small tributary of Crooked River where we camped.  No wood but a few Willows
Friday May 25 1866
Our course was down Buik Creek about 3 miles S.W. to its entrance into the level alkali flat at the head of Crooked River - As we strike the alkali flat we turn about N.N.W and camp on Crooked River about 12 miles below and camped at the crossing of the Yureka and John Day Major Road where in Company with Capt Small (on a Scout) we made our encampment May 27th last year
Saturday May 26 1866
Set out early on the Canyon City Road and camped on Duck Creek where we camped May 28 1865
Sunday May 27 1866
Crossing Duck Creek we bore off over the high hills to the

Camp Watson train was sent out to meet the wagons and returned in the P.M. to the summit prarie [sic] with a portion of the freight  to this Camp and the Wagons came in late with about 200 lbs each but the mud was so horibly [sic] bad that it was impracticable to haul even an empty wagon
Thursday May 31 1866
I went back with the train after the remaining freight which had been left behind which could not be hauled in the Wagons and at night we had it all at the Summit prarie [sic] - Killed a Couple of Deer today which appear to be quite plenty in this section but generally are very wild
Friday June 1 1866
The Teamsters today concluded that they could each take 500 pounds of freight providing the packers could carry the balance which was agreed upon and we set out at on a tolerable early hour.  The summit prarie [sic] was muddy and a stream of about 30 feet wide and flat [?miry?] banks of about 100 yds had to be bridged with bush - The pack animals once over they were started on, but the wagons were delayed and would often drop down into the

on the north side and at about 8 oclock in the evening we are out of the timber and soon arrived at Camp Watson where we found Lieut Barlow in Command

   Having ascertained by actual observation that it would be impracticable to haul our freight over the Mts in the wagons - I secured the pack train which belonged to this Camp to go out [?] aid in the morning

Tuesday May 29 1866
A full supply of meat and other provisions were secured and I set out early and found the pack train and a part of the men at the Summit prarie while the wagons and remainder were encamped in the mud about 8 miles back

  It rained and snowed some in the Mts today
  Lieut Grant having previously tendered his resignation, official notice was reviewed this day that the same had been accepted and that he was mustered out of service 

Wednesday May 30 1866
Our train was rushed on through to Camp Watson - While the

mud so that their beds would rest on top the ground!  I remained with the wagons & it often required that they be pried up out of the mud and bridges built under them and in order handle the obstinate mules to any advantage it often became necessary to unhitch them and move them forward to solid ground and then by the aid of long ropes and poles coupled together the wagons were at length dragged through.

   Passing this point we dragged along through the muddy road to a point near the deep snow on the Summit when we found a quagmire of 75 yds which could not be avoided.  we bridged it with brush a portion of the grass and the teamsters concluding that they could pull through with the aid of ropes and sticks they were directed to go ahead and as soon as they reached the end of our brush causeway the mules sank down to their bellies and layed down and wallowed in the mud as usual and the wagons sank down plumb to the bed
   After much difficulty the mules were placed on solid ground again beyond and

24
and by the further aid of spliced poles & ropes the wagons were [?] through and at about an hour before dark we were on the snow at the summit & found that the wagons could pass over it without sinking into it but a few inches.  our descent on the North side was Comparatively easy and by making a late drive we found ourselves at Camp Watson at about 9 oclock.  We would have Camped before we reached the summit but having two sick men on our wagons who were unable to sit up we deemed it best to push through if possible
Saturday June 2 1866
It had become necessary yesterday to leave a portion of our freight and a squad of men in charge of it back on the Road, and I sent the pack train back for it today
Sunday June  3 1866
The Train arrived today with the rest of our freight and we recd orders in the P.M. to proceed to Ft. Vancouver to be mustered out of service - Therefore was busy all day in turning over property and making Invoices to the H[?]H Q M at this place and making preparations to take our departure to Dept Hed Quarters

Monday June 4 1866
This is general Election throughout the State.  The Oregon Volunteers are all legally entitled to vote for State Officers and are glad we have arrived in time to participate (As soon as the voting commenced it was ruled that the Soldiers Could vote for Co Officers) every one of my company (26) Officers and men voting the Union Ticket
Although they had seen hardships perils and privations such as the State and Government never will realize, yet their patriotism remained unshaken
Tuesday June 5 1866
Everything ready we set out Made 12 miles & camped on Little Cottonwood a tributary of Bridge Creek
Wednesday June 6 1866
A cold morning was stormy & blustering all night accompanied by considerable hail
We found the Road much more muddy than at this Season last year -
We camped on John Days River just below the Mouth of Bridge Creek and several of the men got drunk & had

25 
much fighting among themselves during the night.  their Black eyes and bloody noses next morning told a fearful tale
Thursday June 7 1866
A pleasant day.  reached Current Creek & camped
Friday June 8 1866
This morning a short distance after we set out we met two companies of Regular U.S. Cavalry on their way to Camp Watson and not long afterwards met the Dept. Commander Genl Steel & Staff   The Genl is on a tour of Inspection will visit Camp Watson, Fort Boise and will then proceed to Goose Lake on the South Boundary of the State and locate a Camp or Fort there

  At about 2 PM we arrived at Cross hollows as it is called & here we took what is called the Tyghe Valley Road & following it about 2 miles we Camped on a small branch running north

Saturday June 9 1866
We reached Des Chutes River near the mouth of Tyghe Creek & crossed on the Toll Bridge and camped in a little ravine about a mile or two further where wood & water was to be obtained

26
[postcard with identifying caption: Stanley Del    Sarony, Major & Knapp Liths  449 Broadway NY]
picture show a body of water surrounded by trees and low hills

Sunday June 10 1866
We ascended a long and steep hill for about 2 miles when we found ourselves upon rocky Table land which continue for about 6 miles when we descend a long ravine & pass the narrow valley of Drey Creek and pass over the low divide & Camp in the valley of fifteen Mile Creek - Drey creek valley is narrow and has a handsome tier of farms extending up & down the stream about 20 feet wide & runs of N.E.

   Rev J. H. Wilbur one of the Early missionaries to Oregon with a small Concourse of Citizens came along in the evening and asked permission to preach a Sermon to us which of course was granted -
  It was an interesting sight to contrast the soldiers in their rough garb, ragged & patched clothing long hair and untrimmed beard seated upon the ground listening to the sound of the Gospel with the well dressed men, tidy looking women and interesting little children who had favored us with their presence

Monday June 11 1866
Arrived at the Dalles and marched up to the Garrison & found Capt Gillis in charge

26
our men were assigned to quarters and preparations were made for an early start down the River tomorrow
Tuesday June 12 1866
We went on board the Steamer "Iris" at 5 am and at 10 oclock we found ourselves at the Cascades passing around the Rapids on the Rail Road we went on board the Cascades and were landed at Vancouver at 3 PM and were assigned to quarters in the Garrison
June 13-14-15-15-17
Stayed at Fort Vancouver
Monday June 18 1866
The "Mustering out" Officer being absent at Salem for the purpose of mustering out  H [??] Inf which said Company it appears not yet ready for muster out We were ordered to take our departure this morning for that point and to be mustered out at that place
We went on board the Steamer "Fannie Troupe" and in a short time was at Portland where we were transferred to the "Alert" and were soon at Oregon City

Tuesday June 19 1866
The Company was mustered out at one oclock P.M. by George Williams [13?] Lieut U.S.A. company of Musters and were paid off very soon thereafter by Major Simeon Francis paymaster in the U.S. Army whereupon the men scattered to their various homes in different parts of the County as Citizens while I took my departure in a day or two for the Umpaqua Vally where I arrived in due time
L. L. Williams

27

County Clerkship

   After my discharge from the Military Service I returned to Roseling and in a few days proceeded to Scottsburg and made my home there until Sept when the County clerk of Douglas County sent me word that his deputy Mr. E. H. Lathrop proposed going to the States and wished me to temporarily take his place which I consented to do and was sworn in as Deputy on the 8th day of October 1866
   The County Clerk Mr. R. A. Cowles was suffering from the effects of an old gun shot wound received during the Mexican war and at the present time was severely afflicted only being able to walk on crutches and was only able to be out a portion of the time when the circumstances and weather was favorable.  Consequently the entire duties of the office devolved upon me and by a close and steady application to the business pertaining thereto I managed to give satisfaction to my employer and in the spring following when Mr. Lathrop his former Deputy returned from the Eastern States Mr.

29
Cowles retained me in the office and gave me a much larger portion of the fees than Mr. L required for his services.

  The summer of 1867 passed away and Mr. Cowles health failing gradually he was advised to visit Salem in the Willamette Valley and secure the aid of the Medical faculty at that place:  He remained there until the 25 day of Sept 1867 when he died
  We received a dispatch a few hours later whereupon the County Clerks Office was closed
  The County Judge immediately called an extra session for the purpose of appointing a Clerk which session was held on the 28 day of Sept 1867 and I was appointed to fill the vacancy
  The fall and winter passed away a fine winter with about 4 weeks of cold weather, dry & pleasant ice which froze about 4 inches thick in the ponds and soon after the spring of 1868 was upon us
  The prominent  Union Men of the County were desirous to have me become the Candidate for the Office, but I positively declined although a nomination was equivalent to an election.  I had been absent from my home and relatives in the States for many years.  My Mother and a brother had died

My father was old and feeble and his health fast failing and I had agreed to go home this coming Summer without fail and I felt very much as if I would not like to trust the responsibility to another even for a few moments in case I was elected.  I therefore thanked the party for the many favors they hd bestowed upon me in the past and recommended another person for the place  Mr. E. A. Lathrop who was Deputy under Cowles before I took that position was the nominee of the Convention but about two weeks before the Election he withdrew and Mr. M. M. Melvin was assigned to the place and elected

  My term expired the first Monday in July and Mr. Melvin was sworn in but being quite deficient in the qualifications requisite for the office he insisted that I should remain with him a couple of months and aid and assist him in his various duties but when the two months had expired, he was desirous for me to stay longer and as the Presidential Election was near at hand and having

a strong desire to vote for Grant and Colfax I agreed to stay until the day of Election which event occurred on the 3rd day of Nov 1868

  There appeared to be considerable anxiety manifested among the voting population on both sides
  At the regular Congressional Election in June previous the Democratic party had carried the State by a majority of 1200 but as their ticket at present with Seymour and Blair was not a popular one and our ticket with Grant & Colfax was a popular one the Republican Element had strong hopes of Carrying the State   It went democratic however by a majority of 164 -

Wednesday Nov 4 1868
The Stage for the North left Roseburg at 2 oclock his morning. dark gloom chilly and thick foggy but we rolled on at a fair rate of speed and at daylight we were at Oakland on the Caliposa Creek 17 miles North.

  We left Oakland at sunrise passed through Yoncalla Valley and up Pass Creek a tributary of Elk Creek over the Calipoosa Mts into the head of the Willamette Valley thence down the Valley through handsome farming country to Eugene City a distance of 75 miles where we arrived a couple of hours after dark and found the Union element all alive in their rejoicings over the triumphant election of Grant & Colfax our favorite Standard bearers
 A short stay at Eugene city & we again rolled out and allthough the tightly closed staged [sic] was a fair facsimile of Egyptian darkness I readily recognized the familiar voice of Judge Kelsay of the 2d Judicial Dist of Oregon of which Douglas County forms a part an intimate acquaintance of mine of several years past!  He had been holding Court at Eugene City and was now on his way home to his residence in Corvallis in Benton

Tuesday Nov 3d 1868
The day of the Presidential Election throughout the state was a bright and lovely day.

 My mind was made up and I was ready to start on the Stage tonight to the East to visit my relatives and the scenes of my early childhood in the State of Michigan
 Judge Clayton and Jesse Cadwallader two old pioneers and friends of mine were also going to start at the same time  Clayton to Illinois and Cadwallader to Pennsylvania
 After much speculation as to the route we finally decided to go overland by stage to Portland.  By Steamer up the Columbia to the Umatilla Landing then by stage to Boise City in Idaho and to Salt Lake and on to the Western end of the Union Pacific Rail Road and thence by rail to Chicago
  It was considered to be rather late to make the trip overland but we concluded to try it and thus see a larger scape of Country over which neither of us had ever passed.

County 40 miles farther down the valley where we arrived a couple of hours before daylight
Thursday Nov 5 1868
Corallis is beautifully situated on the left bank of the River and before it was light we were again under way, and after a drive of 10 miles we found ourselves at a point opposite Albany & was soon ferried over the River to the East side and there leaving the River to our left and passing over a oak timbered hilly country we arrived at Salem about 30 miles farther about the middle of the P.M. and at dark we were at Aurora 20 miles beyond and from this place onward the ground appeared rough to ride over was dark and [?right?] damp & heavy foggey;  we found staging anything but pleasant

   Portland contains a population of about  [space left blank] is situated on the West bank of the River about 9 miles from its entrance into theColumbia.  It is the head of navigation for all sea going vessels and is the main commercial center of all northern Oregon

32
and Idaho and a large portion of Washington Territory
Friday Nov 6 1868
Remained in Portland to rest ourselves somewhat after our 200 miles of hard stage travel
Saturday Nov 7 1868
We went on board the Steamer "Cascades" at daylight this morning and soon set out down River in a Northerly Course to its mouth then up the Columbia River in its general East Course touching at Vancouver and arrived at the Cascades of the Columbia a little afternoon [sic] 65 miles from Portland and 165 from Astoria near the Mouth of the River;  We made the Portage by Rail Road on the Washington Territory side about 5 miles to the head of the Rapids or Upper Cascades

   This is one of the noted features of the Columbia River:  The celebrated Range of Cascade Mts are cut in two at this place by might [sic] River Columbia - The Mountains are heavy timbered, high and abrupt, rocky and in many places perpendicular many thousand feet in height
   To this range belongs Mt Hood, Jefferson and other snowy peaks South of us and St Hellens, Adams, Rainier and

33
large and commodious room densely crowded with a gay throng of men and women - A fat beef had been donated for the occasion by the [?Con?] Z. Donnell one of natures noble patriots and it was pleasing to observe the zealous and earnest congratulations which were exchanged consequent upon the success of the Union party and while all hand[sic] done ample justice to Donnells fat beef the entertainment was enlivened music instrumental and vocal by a select choir of ladies & gentlemen and public speaking and cheer upon cheer for the Union, Grant & Colfax, for the Speakers & for Donnell was the order of the evening until a late hour when the dense throng sought their homes deeply impressed with the scenes of the evening long to be remembered.

  Larger crowds may often be assembled together in larger towns upon similar occasions, but in the course of a life time a person will never witness a more happy, jovial or enthusiastic crowd than was assembled at the Union Club room at Dalles City Oregon on the night of November the 7th 1868 to rejoice over the election of Grant & Colfax:  We retired to our hotel at a late hour and the quiet of the City was soon resumed

equally as noted north of us

   The River forms the boundary between Oregon on the South side and Washington Territory on the North side:  The timbered Mts usually reach the River & terminate abruptly and many beautiful rivulets are seen pouring over the rocks & falling in clouds of spray for hundreds of feet
  At the head of the Portage we went on board the Steamer "Idaho" and after a run of 40 miles we were at the Dalles, the Country from the Cascades gradually becoming more open and less timbered and abrupt and by the time we reach the Dalles we find the timber is principly [sic] left behind except scattering pine and a species of scrub oak:
  We found the usual Number of Hacks and Hotel omnibuses at the landing to carry the passengers to the different hotels and at the suggestion of a travelling companion on the Boat we went to the Empire house.  It was nearly night when we arrived and in the evening we attended a grand barbecue at the Grant and Colfax club room which was a

34 
At this point all supplies for the Upper Columbia Country is reshipped and carried by a Rail Road to Celilo a distance of 13 miles. the track of the Road following the River all the way thus avoiding the "Dalles" proper and also the little falls above and which are but a short distance below Celilo 

  This has long been a Military Post of importance and is also the site of one of the first missions established in Oregon
  It has ever been a favorite resort for Indians in consequence of its excellent advantages for fishing
  Situated near the eastern base of the Cascade Mts is therefore Much Colder than points lower down the Colombia or points for several hundred miles above
  Mt. Hood the most famous of the snowy peaks of the Cascade Range always looming up in all it magnificence 30 or 40 miles away on a westerly Course

Monday Nov 9 1868
Stayed at Dalles . a cold bleak day
Tuesday Nov 10 1868
At about 4 oclock this morning we were routed out and went on board the Cars for Celilo - the R.R. Depot is situated at the extreme lower end of

Sunday Nove 8 1868

  We find the the[sic] Up River boats do not leave the landing at [?Celilo?] above until Tuesday morning.  we therefore pass away the day in town.
   Dalles City is an important point the County Seat of Wasco County & contains a population of about 2000 - It is situated on the South side of the River upon a narrow strip of bottom or second [?bench?] land with high bluffs destitute of timber and inclined to be rocky about ¼ mile back from the River:  The City derives its name from the French word "dalles" which was applied by the early voyagers to the rapids or narrows a short distance above town where the River runs through a low trough like channel formed of Basalt with walls of something like 20 feet high and perhaps 100 yds apart -
  The current is rapid and smooth:  upon the banks or in the immediate vicinity of the River there is nothing except the romantic River and its romantic rocky scenery  but back a short distance upon the hills the grass is luxuriant and excellent and the many small valleys are noted for rich fertile soil

35  
3 to 400 yds wide high bluffs generally and a strong Current but we made fair headway and arrived at the Umatilla Landing near the mouth of the Umatilla River at dark.  distance from Portland 150 miles & fare 15 dollars.  We stopped at the "Orleans Hotel" and purchased tickets for Boise City by stage & paid each $40.00:  Arriving late we had but a poor opportunity of seeing the town, but enjoyed ourselves in a short walk through the principal streets and saw sufficient to satisfy ourselves that it was built upon a level sandy plain and that it was of a size sufficient to contain a population of 5 or 600.  It is a brisk little place for the bulk of the Eastern Oregon and Idaho trade passes from this point to the interior by wagons

  We found the most of the houses of the Main streets were open until a late hour and by a careless observer it could be readily seen that it was a pattern of the average of mining towns that Gambling houses  "Hurdy Gurdy" houses and other houses were in the preponderance while the streets were alive with Indians squaws drunken rowdies &c &c going about seeking whom they may devour or seeking an opportunity to steal or to sacrifice

town on the River banks near the Steamboat Landing the track passes through town on Main street and along the River bank to Celilo where we arrived at 5 oclock, distance 13 miles.  the morning was cold thick foggy and disagreeable:  Celilo is the foot of navigation in the open stretch of River above.

  Formerly all freighting from the Dalles was done with wagons which followed up the River about 3 or 4 miles above town and then passed over the hills to the right and again descended from the highlands to the Columbia at the mouth of Des Chutes River about 2 miles above Celilo.  At which point Des Chutes City was built in 1858&9 but was entirely swept away by the high waters of 1861 and was never afterwards rebuilt; Celilo was built soon after but is of but little importance except as being the head of a portage
  Upon our arrival we were transferred from the Cars to the Steamer "Nez-perce chief" which was waiting at  the wharf and we soon had the satisfaction of starting out on our voyage up River with a strong head wind which continued all all [sic] day;   The Columbia is a Magnificent stream from

36
considered the eastern verge of Civilization, but in consequence of the rich gold mines being discovered and opened in the interior in the next season 1862 a large mining population flocked in this direction good wagon roads were built in every direction and at the present time daily stages are arriving and departing from every little town

  We ascend the Blue Mts by the old Emigrants Road which is quite steep for about 2 miles and from thence a gradual ascent for two or 3 miles further when we gradually enter heavy pine timber and the Country assumes a more level or bench like character following these 15 miles we arrived at "Lees Encampment" where a Stage Station and a good hotel is now kept by Hon H.B. Meacham  Upon the Mountains it is found to have stormed considerable of late and the snow is about 4 inches deep:  Passing on at a rapid rate without any particular change in the characteristics of the Country for about 14 miles and descent by a long and gradual descent to the Canyon of Grand Ronde River.  Just before ascending to the River the driver pointed out to us the place where the Stage had been robbed a few days before of its treasure and

the first immodest person they might happen to meet
Wednesday Nov 11 1868
Punctual at 12 ½ oclock this morning we were called up to go on board the stage and was soon whirling along over the dry & dusty plains of the Umatilla in the direction of the Blue Mts   Cold & frosty as usual there has not yet been any rain in the upper country and consequently the dust raised in little clouds and inside the stage it appeared as if we generally had much more than our share

  We reached the Upper Umatilla as it is called at about 10 oclock AM & at this point we expected to obtain breakfast but from some unknown cause to us it did not happen to be ready and the stage being behind time we were obliged to move on,  We crossed the River at this point and followed along and near the old Emigrant road and reached the foot of the Blue Mts at Noon and here we eat our breakfast and dinner combined in one
  The weather blustering & chilly

  The road follows down the River to its entrance into Grand Ronde Valley and at about 11 oclock at night we was at "Lagrande" at stopped at the only hotel at the place
  Grand Round Valley was settled in 1862 and contains a thrifty farming population and has the honor of supporting two or three small towns:  Three hours sleep could be had before the Boise City stage would leave and Cadwallader & myself went to bed much fatigued
  Our hotel was one peculiar to the frontiers is used for hotel, store  ware house - dwelling house. whiskey shop &c - A kind of barroom or sitting was filled up with old boxes. stove wood - [?Aparahoes?]. saddles & rigging and a great variety of old traps far too numerous to mention to say nothing of the dogs and Indians and dirty young ones that occupied the principal space around a small stove the only warming aparatus [sic] in the room
  We paid a dollar each for the privilege of a bed for the two or three hours remaining before we was to set out,
  At three different hours during the night different stages arrive and depart and upon the arrival of our stage

and the passengers of their money and valuables:  The point selected by the Robbers was where the road began to descend a hill and a clump of large pines standing at the side of the road formed an excellent shelter and of course they were not seen until they stepped out in their usual manner with double barrel shot guns and Revolvers at full cock and demanded the Driver to stop the passengers to alight.  those kind of persuasions generally command respect and prompt obedience the Robbery was soon Consumated and no one harmed and the stage alowed [sic] to move on  these robberies are of frequent occurrence in this region of country and whenever driver & passengers are quick to obey are seldom followed by the loss of life but whenever reluctant or slow to move or unwilling to yield up their money or other valuables or make any resistance the loss of life always follows.

As a general thing the Country is not adapted to agriculture yet some good patches of farming land is to be found . good grass for grazing purposes exist everywhere . passing several miles over the level dusty plains of Powder River Vally we arrive at a small town Called Baker City the County seat of Baker County (named after Col Baker) and soon after leave the vally and pass over a low range of hills to the headwaters of a branch of Burnt [Malheur crossed out] River which we follow down to a station called Express Ranch . where a man by the name of Scott and his wife were murdered by the Indians about 3 weeks ago. their house burned together with the Stage Station and other buildings : The station has been rebuilt, but the ruins and the two newly made graves near by were the fearful mementos of Savage barbarism so often seen upon the frontiers

another was ready to set out and as our LandLord piloted us to bed, he at the same time called up two others to go on board the departing stage and as they got out of bed we tumbled in to it.  the bed consisted of solid plank. a thin straw mattress, 3 blankets and no pillows. Thursday Nov 12 1868
At 2 oclock this morning we were under way in an open wagon. cold and foggy and disagreeable . we reached "Uniontown" near the head of the vally a little before daylight and daylight soon appearing in the East we left the Grand Ronde Vally and passed over a low range of hills into Powder River vally:  The day cold & clear, roads horribly dusty: Gold mines were discovered upon Powder River and its tributaries in 1862 and have been worked to a considerable extent ever since . and in Consequence thereof thrifty settlements have

had supper and an hour or two rest and enjoyed the luxury of a good fire :  At this station I found an old acquaintance of mine John [?Hulse?] formerly from the Umpqua Vally acting in the Capacity of hostler
Friday Nov 13 1868
We were off from the last mentioned ranch in due time

  We had lain down and all hands were sound asleep before the fire.  It seemed like murder in the first degree to get up and start out.  Ice was about an inch thick in the water bucket : Five miles on brought us to Snake River the Main South fork of the Columbia which we crossed in a ferry boat : stream swift and about 200 yds wide and forms the boundary between Orgon [sic] and Idaho
  Following up stream a few miles on the opposite side, we forded the [?Weiser?] a stream of about 150 yds wide emptying in to the Snake a short distance below . and soon after crossed the Payette a similar stream & from this point our course was up Payette vally a few miles over a level sage plain dusty when we bear off

39
from the River to the right across the plain to the low range of sage hills over which the road passes and we soon descend to the wide and extensive sage plains bording upon the Boise River vally . the River being off to the right : we Continued up the Boise Vally approaching nearer & nearer to the River and at 11 oclock at night we were at Boise City, the Capital of Idaho Territory  .  distance from the Umatilla Landing on the Columbia River 280 miles . Time 3 days, fare 40 dollars . and meals 1 dollar each
Saturday Nov 14 1868
We had no opportunity to explore the City . but hastened to the Sage Office and secured tickets to Salt Lake City . 75 dollars coin or 100 in GreenBacks - Was informed by the Agent that the seats were all taken but 3 and as that was just our number we went on board & set set [sic] out in the chilly darkness, crossing Boise River and afterwards Malade River . and proceeded on in an easterly direction with perhaps a slight bearing to the Southward over the broken hilly country for the Upper Snake River ferry

  At daylight this morning we were at the Snake River ferry 130 miles from Boise City, where we took breakfast at the station which appeared to have a woman for one of its inmates . but whose duty appeared to be something more lofty than that of Catering for the traveling public

the voice of one of our new fellow passengers who had joined us at Boise City . and as soon as a favorable opportunity afforded . The nights are becoming colder & colder.  Ice freezes thick in every little branch and around every spring . Last night it was with much difficulty that we could keep warm. Tuesday Nov 17 1868
We set out from Bear River a little after dark and passing through several little mining towns among which was Brigham City and Box Elder. we found ourselves at Ogden City at daylight.

   Having a brother living near this place whom I had not seen for 17 years, I concluded to stop a day or two while the remainder of the party continued on to Salt Lake to await at that point until my arrival
   I found my brother during the day living on a little bit of a farm in a comfortable board house with a wife and five or six children . and a full fledged Mormon
   I stayed at his place the remainder of the day and also next day and on

Thursday Nov 19
I again took the Stage at Ogden City and set out for the City of the Saints about 36 miles South of here and near the South end of the Lake.  the road was along and near the Lake over a level

plain the most of the way . with a high and abrupt range of Mountains a few miles to the Eastward : Perhaps over half the distance from Ogden to Salt Lake City is settled and small mormon villages appear at short intervals : The Lake is not far to your right all the time in full view with numerous Mountainous Islands among which are Fremonts Island and Antelope Island : We arrived at the city at about 3.30 PM. and prepare to set out at dark

Friday Nov 20th 1868
At day light this morning we were on a high summit ridge with considerable snow around about us in sight and was about to descend into the Valley of the Weber River which runs into Salt Lake through the valley near Ogden City
